At least, that's what Senator John McCain may be saying now that he has been named the ''fastest-falling'' Google search this year, according to 2009 search trends released Tuesday by the company. The search numbers, which Google has collected since 2001, illustrate Americans' anxieties and passions and, most notably this year, how big government programs inspired intense curiosity.

docs.snippet: Google's new domain name system has a rival questioning the search giant's motives....
docs.lead_paragraph: People typically lunge for metaphors when trying to describe the Internet's Domain Name System, or D.N.S., so here's mine: think of D.N.S. as one of those switchboard operators at the old Ma Bell telephone company. Each Internet service provider has its own bank of these operators, called D.N.S. servers. Type in a Web address - nytimes.com, for example - and the ISP's operator looks up the numerical IP address of the site and connects the call.

headline.main: Pondering Google's Move Into the D.N.S. Business

docs.lead_paragraph: In recent months, tech blogs have been abuzz with rumors that Google is planning to market its own smartphone based on its Android operating system. The plan would signal a more aggressive effort by Google, which so far has relied on partners to build and market Android phones, to become a force in mobile devices. It could also put Google at odds with those partners, which include Verizon Wireless and Motorola, and it would sharpen its competition with Apple, whose iPhone dominates the high-end smartphone market in the United States.

headline.main: ‘Googled’

docs.snippet: Every species -- be it earthworm or great white shark -- is entwined in a vast and complicated system of predator and prey called a food web. To determine which species in a food web are most important to the survival of the larger ecosystem, scie...
docs.lead_paragraph: Every species -- be it earthworm or great white shark -- is entwined in a vast and complicated system of predator and prey called a food web. To determine which species in a food web are most important to the survival of the larger ecosystem, scientists design computer programs to model how the extinction of a given species would affect the other species in the system. This year, two scientists announced that they had found an unexpectedly useful tool for this purpose: the seminal Google search algorithm. Stefano Allesina of the University of Chicago and Mercedes Pascual of the University of Michigan began with a simple hunch. Google's search engine uses an algorithm called PageRank to identify the most important Web sites on a given topic by analyzing links: a Web page is important if other important pages link to it. How different is this, really, Allesina and Pascual wondered, from an ecosystem, in which a species is important if other important species eat it?

headline.main: Google Algorithm as Extinction Model, The

docs.abstract: Stefano Allesina of University of Chicago and Mercedes Pascual of University of Michigan use PageRank, google algorithm, to map food web and develop ecosystem-extinction model; research is published in journal PLoS Computational Biology; drawing (M)

docs.snippet: When Michael Jackson moonwalked off this mortal coil in June, the outgoing King of Pop unwittingly ushered in a new era on the Internet: the age of real-time search.     If you wanted the scoop on what had just happened that day, the place to look...
docs.lead_paragraph: When Michael Jackson moonwalked off this mortal coil in June, the outgoing King of Pop unwittingly ushered in a new era on the Internet: the age of real-time search. If you wanted the scoop on what had just happened that day, the place to look for it wasn't Google News, which featured hours-old stories from The Associated Press and other news wires. The sites to hit were goofy-named start-ups like Topsy, OneRiot and Wowd. These companies crawl social networks like Twitter and Facebook to show you what people are saying right this second and, just as important, what they're linking to.

headline.main: Web Searches in Real Time

docs.abstract: Real-time search, which took off in hours and days following death of music icon Michael Jackson, has become hot new topic of those in Internet industry; examples of real-time Web sites and applications described (M)

headline.main: App of the Week: Google’s Eyes on the Ground
headline.print_headline: App of the Week: Google’s Eyes on the Ground

docs.snippet: GoogleGoggles is a new free app for smartphones using the Android operating system. With its grab bag of features, the app is a bit hard to define. Goggles uses a phone's camera for data entry, Web searching and shopping, with a little bit of augm...
docs.lead_paragraph: GoogleGoggles is a new free app for smartphones using the Android operating system. With its grab bag of features, the app is a bit hard to define. Goggles uses a phone's camera for data entry, Web searching and shopping, with a little bit of augmented reality thrown in. Here's how it works. You use your phone to take a photo of a building, artwork, a bar code or some text and Goggles identifies it and brings back Google search results. A photo of a book cover brought back links to where the book is sold online, reviews, a Wikipedia entry on the author and more. A picture of the exterior of a restaurant brings back reviews, links to the restaurant's Web site and a link to call the place with one click.

headline.main: App of the Week: Google's Eyes on the Ground

docs.abstract: Google app for smartphones running Android operating system uses phone's camera for data entry, Web searching and other 'augmented reality' features; photo (S)

docs.snippet: In a sign that Google is interested in broadening its reach in the local business market, the search giant is in acquisition talks with Yelp, the review site for local businesses....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google is in discussions to buy Yelp, the Web site that lists and reviews local businesses, according to three people who had been briefed on the negotiations. The talks show how intently the biggest Web companies are setting their sights on the smallest neighborhood businesses, where they see a large and untapped group of advertisers. Google and Yelp have not signed an agreement, the people said. The people would not disclose the proposed price, but one said it was more than $500 million.

headline.main: Google Said To Be Near A Yelp Deal

docs.abstract: Three sources report that Google is in discussions to purchase Yelp, Website that lists and rates local businesses for consumer reference; say that no agreement has been reached; deal is part of larger trend toward localization of information that can be utilized by smartphone technologies; adding local base of information would likely allow companies to increase advertising revenues from small businesses that still rely heavily on word of mouth and Yellow Pages; photo (M)

byline.original: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER; Miguel Helft contributed reporting

docs.snippet: Google was ordered to stop putting scanned French books in its database and to pay about $430,000 in damages....
docs.lead_paragraph: A French court ruled on Friday that Google infringed copyrights by digitizing books and putting extracts online without authorization, dealing a setback to its embattled book project. The court in Paris ruled against Google after a publishing group, La Martinière, backed by publishers and authors, argued that the industry was being exploited by Google's Book Search program, which was started in 2005.

headline.main: Paris Court Orders Google to Stop Digitizing French Books and Pay Damages

docs.abstract: Paris court rules in favor of La Martiniere, publishing group, and orders Google to stop digitizing books and putting excerpts online without authorization; Google must also pay $430,000 in damages and interest to La Martiniere and remove content from online database; Google argues that it followed French copyright law and plans to appeal decision; photo (M)

byline.original: By MATTHEW SALTMARSH; John Rofé contributed reporting

headline.seo: Google Goggles, Searching by Image Alone
headline.main: Snap and Search (No Words Needed)

docs.snippet: Google’s data centers distribute images among hundreds or even thousands of computers to identify them....
docs.lead_paragraph: THE world, like the World Wide Web before it, is about to be hyperlinked. Soon, you may be able to find information about almost any physical object with the click of a smartphone. This vision, once the stuff of science fiction, took a significant step forward this month when Google unveiled a smartphone application called Goggles. It allows users to search the Web, not by typing or by speaking keywords, but by snapping an image with a cellphone and feeding it into Google's search engine.

headline.main: Snap And Search (No Words Needed)

docs.abstract: Google Inc's new Goggles smartphone application promises to bridge gap between physical world and Internet by allowing users to search Web by snapping image with cellphone and feeding it into Google's search engine; Google vice president Vic Gundotra says project's ultimate goal is recognition of every image; such technology, if perfected, would offer host of commercial applications; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Twitter is said to be in-the-black for the first time since its founding in 2006. Bloomberg News, citing unidentified people, said that Twitter made $25 million in profit in 2009 from Internet search deals with Google and Microsoft. That may be a good start, but does it mean that its $1 billion valuation is right?

docs.lead_paragraph: Word came last week that Google was looking to buy Yelp, the ubiquitous consumer-ratings service that can serve as guide when you need a certain kind of food (say falafel) in a certain town (let's say Portland.) Yelp's ratings are hardly foolproof, but having some knowledge of what other consumers thought of a place is far better than just taking your chances.

docs.abstract: Yelp tie-up with Google off for the time being, but remains alluring as a route to the grail of local digital ad sales.

Professional organizations and major technology companies, including Google, Microsoft and Intel support the broad agenda, though companies are not getting into curriculum details.

docs.abstract: A move to encourage computer education reflects the concern that people will be divided between those who understand technology and those who are ruled by it.

docs.snippet: Motorola tugged at the hearts of science-fiction fans when it announced that its first smartphone using Google's Android software would be called Droid, the name given to the lovable robots in ''Star Wars.''     Google appears to be trying the sam...
docs.lead_paragraph: Motorola tugged at the hearts of science-fiction fans when it announced that its first smartphone using Google's Android software would be called Droid, the name given to the lovable robots in ''Star Wars.'' Google appears to be trying the same tactic with its own soon-to-be-released Android phone. The device is called Nexus One in at least two government filings.

headline.main: Name for a Google Phone Stirs Anger

docs.snippet: Google is nearing a deal to buy the start-up Docverse, TechCrunch reported, citing unidentified sources. The deal is said to be worth about $25 million, and is just one of a series that the Internet giant is making as it challenges Microsoft for d...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google is nearing a deal to buy the start-up Docverse, TechCrunch reported, citing unidentified sources. The deal is said to be worth about $25 million, and is just one of a series that the Internet giant is making as it challenges Microsoft for dominance in the word-processing sector.

headline.main: Many Small Buys as Google Assails Office

docs.abstract: Google is nearing a deal to buy the start-up Docverse, TechCrunch reported, citing unidentified sources. The deal is said to be worth about $25 million, and is just one of a series that the Internet giant is making as it challenges Microsoft for dominance in the word processing sector.

docs.snippet: A report in the Bits column on Monday about objections to the potential name for a new Google phone misidentified the company that licensed the name ''Droid'' from Lucasfilm for use with a Motorola phone. It was Verizon Wireless, not Motorola itse...
docs.lead_paragraph: A report in the Bits column on Monday about objections to the potential name for a new Google phone misidentified the company that licensed the name ''Droid'' from Lucasfilm for use with a Motorola phone. It was Verizon Wireless, not Motorola itself.

headline.main: Corrections

docs.snippet: A well-timed employee stock option exchange has delivered a generous windfall to nearly all of Google's 20,000 workers--about $117,000....
docs.lead_paragraph: Like many companies, Google has a tradition of giving holiday presents to its employees -- an Android phone last year, $1,000 in cash net of taxes the year before. This year, they got Google's soon-to-be-released phone.

docs.snippet: Google has a tradition of giving holiday presents to its employees -- an Android phone last year, $1,000 in cash net of taxes the year before. This year, they got Google's not-yet-released Nexus One phone.     But most Googlers got an early holida...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google has a tradition of giving holiday presents to its employees -- an Android phone last year, $1,000 in cash net of taxes the year before. This year, they got Google's not-yet-released Nexus One phone. But most Googlers got an early holiday gift far more worthy of envy.

headline.main: Gift for Googlers: $2.3 Billion

docs.snippet: Google invites reporters to an Android event next week, raising expectations that it will unveil the Nexus One phone....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google just invited reporters to an "Android press gathering" on Jan. 5. Google representatives declined to provide any further details about the event, but by all appearances this will be the unveiling of the Nexus One, the Google-designed phone that the company plans to market directly to consumers.

headline.main: Is Google's Nexus One Phone Landing Next Week?

docs.abstract: Google invites reporters to an Android event next week, raising expectations that it will unveil the Nexus One phone.

docs.abstract: Lucid Imagination, an open-source start-up, hopes to rival the likes of Microsoft and Google in the market for corporate search technology.

docs.snippet: From announcements about new iPhones and e-readers to a mysterious apparition in Google Earth, a look back at which blog posts captured readers' attention in 2009....
docs.lead_paragraph: From announcements about next-generation technology products to speculation about whether the biggest computer virus of the year was actually a big practical joke and mysterious sightings in Google Earth, here is a list of the Top 10 stories on Bits that captured our readers' attention. We were surprised by a couple ourselves.

headline.main: The Most-Viewed Bits Posts of 2009

docs.abstract: From announcements about new iPhones and e-readers to a mysterious apparition in Google Earth, a look back at which blog posts captured readers' attention in 2009.
